JavaScript Weekly

The State of Web Workers in 2021 â€” The web is typically single-threaded, but two years ago Surma told us why to always use Web Workers to bring multithreading to your solutions despite the difficulties. Almost every client supports them now, so Surma makes the case again and explains why Web Workers deserve a place in yourÂ projects.

Its rollout as a default after every npm install was rushed, inconsiderate, and inadequate for the front-end tooling.â€ Dan adopts an untypically critical tone but does a good job of demonstrating how vulnerabilities are not all alike when it comes to whether they matter.

A Look at Building with Astro â€” Astro, which we featured a month ago, is a new framework for building sites where you get to use JavaScript frameworks but sites are rendered in staticÂ form.

  • How about a two-player self hosted Tic-tac-toe game in 640 bytes ofÂ JavaScript?

items.content:
#â€‹544 â€” June 25, 2021

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

ES2021 Now Approved; Here's the Features (Quickly) â€” Weâ€™ve linked to a short and sweet code-based summary of the big new features, but the actual news is that the Ecma General Assembly has approved ES2021. Work continues with ECMAScript 2022 already having a draft spec. The FinalizationRegistry is an interesting addition for requesting a callback for when an object is garbageÂ collected.

Hemanth HM

â–¶Â Â Coding Up a Mario Game in JavaScript with Kaboom.js â€” Ania is back showing us how to create a basic platformer in the course of an hour in her typically breezy, easy to followÂ manner. Watch this if you want to reignite that codingÂ spark.

Ania KubÃ³w

Better Onboarding: How to Prevent Codebase Overwhelm â€” Code complexity is increasing, and for new developers joining a team or project, the steep learning curve can be intimidating, confusing, even demoralizing. Learn more about best practices for onboarding and how to get up to speedÂ fast.

Sourcegraph sponsor

Parsing in JavaScript: The Tools and Libraries You Can Use â€” From libraries to parser generators, a look at a variety of options for parsing languages (existing or perhaps of your own creation) inÂ JavaScript.

  • Vercel, formerly ZEIT, is a popular deployment platform in the JavaScript world and they maintain Next.js. They've just raised $102M which will partly go to pushing Next.js forward.

items.content:
#â€‹543 â€” June 18, 2021

UnsubscribeÂ Â |Â Â Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Benchmarking JavaScript Memory Usage â€” Historically, memory usage hasnâ€™t been a heavily tracked thing in the JavaScript world, whether for a lack of tooling or motivation. This is changing, and new tools and APIs are turning up all the time. Here, Tim has done some analysis of what the top 10k Web sites are using in terms of memory and, perhaps controversially, how the choice of framework can affectÂ things.

Tim Kadlec (WebPageTest)

Dr. Axel Explains Three ECMAScript Proposals â€” JavaScriptâ€™s inimitable doctor is blogging again and has examined the â€˜error causeâ€™ proposal (a way to let Error instances specify if they were caused by another error), JSON modules (a way to import data as if it were an ES module), and Accessible Object.prototype.hasOwnProperty() (a way to check if an object has an own/non-inherited property).

Dr. Axel Rauschmayer

Take Control of Your Core Web Vitals with Raygun â€” Don't be a bystander when Core Web Vitals are released as a ranking factor by Google. In this in-depth walkthrough, our expert team follows a proven process to monitor and improve Core Web Vitals with Raygun, and give you the power to do theÂ same.

Raygun sponsor

Next.js 11 Released â€” The popular React framework takes some more steps forward with improved performance, Webpack 5 support, an experimental way to make Create React App apps Next.js compatible, and Next.js Live, a preview of a way to build Next.js apps in the browser, collaboratively, with yourÂ team.

Next.js Team

ğŸ’¡ If you happen to use React a lot, be sure to check out our React newsletterÂ too.

Quick Bits

  • Gleam is a type-safe language for the Erlang virtual machine and it can now compile to JavaScript which opens up some new interesting frontend possibilities.
  • GitHub's CEO has noted that 4 billion packages are downloaded each day from the official npm registry.
  • Did you know you can use underscores to make numbers easier to read? For example: 1_000_000
  • The Angular project has updated its roadmap covering both in-progress improvements and future initiatives.
  • V8 has added support for import assertions.

Releases

NeutralinoJS 2.3.0 â€” Cross-platform desktop app dev framework.
SVG.js 3.1 â€” Easier manipulation of SVG from JS.
ws 7.5.0 â€” WebSocket client and server for Node.js.
Intro.js 4.1 â€” Easy user onboarding approach.
Tailwind CSS 2.2 â€” Popular CSS framework.

Deno 1.11 Released â€” A variety of enhancements in the latest release of the alternative server-side V8-powered JavaScriptÂ runtime:

  • The Deno project now supplies official Docker images.
  • You can now abort fetch requests in a Web-compatible way.
  • deno lint is now considered stable.
  • BroadcastChannel brings support for broadcasting messages amongst Web Workers.

Deno Core Team

My favorite roundup is this one which tackles the big picture in the first five minutes but then goes into a little more depth if you wantÂ it.

Harry Wolff

When CSS Isnâ€™t Enough: JavaScript Requirements For Accessible Components â€” Stephanie Eckles looks at how components such as tooltips, modals, tabs, carousels, and dropdown menus often require more than just CSS (even when 'pure CSS' solutions are technically possible), especially to ensureÂ accessibility.

Smashing Magazine

Infrastructure as Code using JavaScript and Pulumi â€” Use the JavaScript language and ecosystem to manage and provision infrastructure across any cloud and a variety ofÂ workloads.

Pulumi sponsor

Examples of New Browser APIs to Detect JS Performance Problems inÂ Production â€” Basic coverage of using performance.now(), the Long Task API (with PerformanceObserver), the Event Timing API, and the JavaScript Self-ProfilingÂ API.

Michael Shpilt

Embedding Vue.js Apps in Go(lang) â€” With Go 1.16â€™s embed, you can now include frontend assets directly in a Go binary, making a full-stack server deployment as simple as running a single executableÂ file.

Trevor Taubitz

A Visual Guide to Node.js Streams â€” Streams arenâ€™t conceptually too difficult to grasp but some visuals fit well and certainlyÂ help.

Deepal Jayasekara

Drawing Graphics with the CSS Paint API â€” A practical introduction to the CSS Paint API with hands-on code examples including particles, noise buttons and curvyÂ dividers.

Georgi Nikolov

5 Reasons Not to Write Your JavaScript Data Grid from Scratch

MathJax 3.2.0: Beautiful Math Rendering in All Browsers â€” Youâ€™re smarter than me if you know what that formula represents, but it looks nice.. v3.2.0 dropped yesterday. GitHubÂ repo.

MathJax

Viewer.js 1.10: A Flexible JavaScript Image Viewer â€” We first linked this almost five years ago, but itâ€™s still kept updated. If youâ€™ve got a group of images to show, this provides user controls to move between them, zoom (including with gestures), rotate, and such like. GitHubÂ repo.

Chen Fengyuan

Breakpoints and console.log Is the Past, Time Travel Is the Future â€” 15x faster JavaScript debugging than with breakpoints andÂ console.log.

Wallaby.js sponsor

Remote Repositories Extension for Visual Studio Code â€” If you use VS Code, this extension from GitHub itself offers a quicker way to open GitHub repos remotely direct from theÂ editor.

Microsoft

Undici 4.0: An HTTP Client, Written from Scratch for Node â€” The goal of this project has been to replace Nodeâ€™s core HTTP library with something faster, more scalable, and without the â€˜fundamental design issuesâ€™ of the core API. v4 introduces redirect support, a faster WASM-powered parser, and a native mocking layer. GitHubÂ repo.

Nagy, Collina, et al.

A Pathfinding Algorithm Visualizer â€” A fun tool for visualizing different pathfinding algorithms (essentially ways to find routes from one point to another). Hereâ€™s the source if you want to dig deeper, including theÂ algorithms.

Joseph Prichard
